intro: Quercus virginiana subsp. dentata, commonly known as the Florida栎 or the water oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in the fall, and its acorns are typically enclosed in a cupule. The tree has a broad, spreading canopy and can grow up to 50 feet tall. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal areas and wetlands. Its botanical features make it an important species for both ecological and ornamental purposes.
